title: stellar mapping Rotation Analysis
description: Joffrey Beezooos's solar array controller spent 23 minutes calculating how to turn a fuel systems diagram sideways. It kept asking 'If I move this corner here, where do the other three corners go?' while the human operator just tilted their head. 90-degree rotations combine spatial reasoning with coordinate transformation. AI must understand how positions change in 2D space while maintaining object relationships - a complex geometric abstraction that requires true spatial intelligence. Analyze the stellar mapping by rotating the input grid 90 degrees clockwise üîÅ.
hints: When you turn a picture sideways, you just know what it looks like. But computers have to figure out where every single dot should move when you spin something. It's like doing a puzzle where every piece changes places.

Think about when you turn your head to look at something sideways. You don't have to think about it - you just do it. But a computer is like someone who has to carefully move every toy in your room to new spots just to see what it looks like from a different angle.

It's like playing with a kaleidoscope. When you turn it, all the pretty colors move to new places, but you can still see it's the same pattern. A computer would have to track where each tiny piece of color went and calculate its new home.
Rotate the entire grid 90 degrees clockwise üîÉ (¬º turn to the right).
The top row becomes the rightmost column, reading from top to bottom.
Each column in the original becomes a row in the result, with order reversed.
